name: Linux Enumeration Basics
description: Comprehensive manual enumeration of a Linux system to gather information for privilege escalation, lateral movement, or post-exploitation.

steps.name: Basic System Information
steps.description: Retrieve kernel version, distribution details, hostname, and current user privileges to understand the environment.

steps.name: User and Group Enumeration
steps.description: List users with shell access, groups, and sudo privileges to identify potential targets or misconfigurations.

steps.name: Password and Shadow Files
steps.description: Check for SSH keys in common locations and attempt to read hashed passwords if accessible.

steps.name: Running Processes and Services
steps.command: ps aux | grep -v '^root' | grep -v '^$' ; ss -tuln || netstat -tuln 2>/dev/null
steps.description: Identify non-root processes that might be exploitable and list listening ports for network services.

steps.name: File System and Permissions
steps.command: find / -type f -perm -u=s 2>/dev/null | grep -v '^/proc'; find / -writable -type d 2>/dev/null | head -20
steps.description: Locate SUID binaries for potential privilege escalation and writable directories for persistence or modification.

steps.name: Cron Jobs and Scheduled Tasks
steps.description: Inspect system-wide and user cron jobs for scripts running as root that may be editable.

steps.name: Kernel Exploits and Modules
steps.command: cat /proc/version; lsmod | grep -i vuln || echo 'Check manually'; dmesg | grep -i vuln 2>/dev/null
steps.description: Gather kernel details for known exploits (search exploit-db with uname output) and check loaded modules.

steps.name: Configuration and Log Files
steps.description: Review mounted filesystems, accessible logs for credentials or errors, and sensitive config files.

steps.name: Network Configuration
steps.command: ip a; ip route; cat /etc/hosts; arp -a || cat /proc/net/arp
steps.description: Enumerate interfaces, routing, hosts file, and ARP table for internal network reconnaissance.

steps.name: Sensitive Files and History
steps.description: Check command history for credentials and search for backup or configuration files containing secrets.
